Question Text: Given the following IP address - 20.54.23.3 and subnet mask - 255.255.255.0 choose the subnet ID and the broadcast address from that particular IP.
Choices:
a. Subnet ID: 20.54.23.0
Broadcast Address: 20.54.23.255
b. Subnet ID: 20.54.0.0
Broadcast Address: 20.54.0.255
c. Subnet ID: 20.54.0.0
Broadcast Address: 20.54.255.255
d. Subnet ID: 20.54.23.1
Broadcast Address: 20.54.23.255
LLM Explanation: The subnet mask 255.255.255.0 indicates that the first three octets (20.54.23) represent the network portion of the IP address, while the last octet (.3) represents the host portion. The subnet ID is found by setting all host bits to 0, resulting in 20.54.23.0. The broadcast address is found by setting all host bits to 1, resulting in 20.54.23.255.

In this mask, the first two octets have all bits set to 1, corresponding to 255 in decimal. The third octet has the two most significant bits set to 1, which is 192 in decimal. The last octet has all bits set to 0, which is simply 0 in decimal.

The second octet (11100000) is 224 in decimal, as only the first three bits are set. The third and fourth octets are all zeros, so they convert to 0 in decimal. Therefore, the correct decimal representation of the given binary mask is 255.224.0.0.

Question Text: R1 and R2 are attached to the same Ethernet VLAN, with subnet 192.168.1.0/24, and addresses 192.168.1.1, 192.168.2 respectively. The routers use an FHRP. Host A and host B attach to the same LAN and have correct default router settings per the FHRP configuration. Which of the following statements is true for this LAN?
Choices:
a. You can't connect two routers to the same LAN subnet.
b. If one router fails, hosts can't send packets off-subnet
c. If one router fails, both hosts will use the one remaining router as a default router
d. if one router fails, only one of the two hosts will still be able to send packets off-subnet
LLM Explanation: In a LAN with two routers using a First Hop Redundancy Protocol (FHRP) like HSRP or VRRP, if one router fails, the other router will take over as the active router. All hosts on the LAN will then use the remaining active router as their default gateway to send packets off-subnet. The FHRP ensures that there is always an active router available to forward traffic, providing redundancy and preventing a single point of failure.
